results.title: Bodysurfer. - Volume 2.
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Ross Matthews and Ian Barry
results.brief_description: Based on the award-winning collection of short-stories by Robert Drewe, Bodysurfer combines a number of characters and incidents to create a single narrative focusing on the troubled personal life of David Lang. Following the failure of his marriage he begins a series of casual affairs but memories of his past come flooding back to stir his feelings of guilt. Realising he has failed his son, he becomes a fugitive to reconsider his future. Cast includes Peter Kowitz, Linda Cropper, Joy Smithers and Penne Hackforth-Jones.

results.title: Bodyspeak
results.creator_credit: New Zealand Film Commission and Gregor Nicholas
results.brief_description: Bodyspeak juxtaposes elaborate dances from different cultures, each carrying its ritual significance in the highly disciplined gestures and movements of the performers. Notions of sexual/cultural difference and prejudice are examined through techniques of cultural collision and juxtaposition. No commentary - music only.

results.title: Bodyheat = Body heat
results.creator_credit: Ladd Company, Warner Bros Pictures, Fred Gallo and Lawrence Kasdan
results.brief_description: Kathleen Turner made her acting debut and Kasdan his directorial debut, in this modern day “film noir”, with a plot resembling that of “Double Indemnity”. Set in Florida, William Hurt plays attorney Ned Racine. His involvement with the seductive Matty Walker, played by Turner, leads him down the path to murder as they plot to kill her husband, played by Richard Crenna. Turner and Hurt’s performances are excellent, yet the film received mixed reactions. Some critics applauded Kasdan’s effort to translate the “film noir” genre of the 1940’s into the more sexually permissable 1980’s, while others saw it as a poor remake of a film classic. “Body Heat” has the elements of steamy passion, intrigue and murder and features Ted Danson and Mickey Rourke in supporting roles.

results.title: Body, Mind and Massage - Relaxing Together
results.brief_description: This creative video is a guide to relaxation and health improvement through the science and art of massage in a format especially designed for couples. Learn how to use time together for regular periods of massage therapy that can release stress and tension, relieve muscular pain and fatigue, reduce sinus conditions or headaches, even improve circulation. Fully demonstrated, easy to follow instructions allow you to quickly learn the basic principles and techniques of massage. Rated: G

results.title: Body talking
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, George Johnson, John Taylor and Don White
results.brief_description: This engaging short film designed for Language and Visual Arts activities in grades 3 to 6 looks at a non-verbal form of communication that is universally understood - body language. With a candid camera and a catchy song, Body Talking demonstrates how our posture, gestures and facial expressions can tell others a great deal about how we’re feeling. Scenes in parks and playgrounds, on city streets and at bus stops show that “without saying a word, we can still be heard” - when our body does the talking. (Award: Vancouver)

results.title: Body of evidence
results.creator_credit: De Laurentiis Entertainment Group, Dino De Laurentiis and Uli Edel
results.brief_description: An erotic thriller and murder mystery, “Body of evidence” is probably best remembered for the brouhaha surrounding the sado-masochistic sex games played out before the camera by actors Madonna and Willem Dafoe. Madonna plays a beautiful, sexually aggressive seductress named Rebecca who has a penchant for perilous peccadillos preferably conducted with wealthy men of poor heart condition. When one partner dies in the throes of passion, leaving Rebecca eight million dollars, she is charged with murder. Dafoe plays Frank Dulaney, an ambitious attorney who takes on the case, and despite being uncertain of Rebecca’s innocence, is soon drawn into an amorous relationship that belies his history as a loyal family man. A courtroom drama, not entirely dissimilar in structure to “Witness for the prosecution” (Hitchcock, 1957), this film was released in the wake of the hit “Basic instinct”, but despite matching its salaciousness (and silliness), failed to replicate its success at the box-office. Contains explicit sex scenes and situations but has quite predictably, a morally conservative outcome.

results.title: Body melt
results.creator_credit: 1 for Dumb Films, Australian Film Commission, Film Victoria, Rod Bishop, Daniel Scharf and Philip Brophy
results.brief_description: Something weird is happening in suburban Pebbles Court, Homesville. The residents are unknowingly part of a diabolical experiment with a radical ‘90’s body drug. Some will survive but most will not! The first phase is hallucinogenic, the second phase is glandular and the third phase is Body Melt! “An inventive and laudably tasteless journey into the surreal” Sight & Sound (UK). “Packs more mucous, phlegm, puke, snot, slime and spit than you ever thought possible” Starburst (UK). If you enjoyed “Salt, saliva, sweat and sperm” in the ‘80’s by the same producers and director, then this is the ‘90’S experience you have been craving! Based on four short stories by Philip Brophy. Starring Gerard Kennedy, Ian Smith, Andrew Daddo, Lisa McCune, Brett Climo, Vince Gil and William McInnes.
